guide.introduction: Tired of all those LCD TVs everywhere? Want a break from advertisements while you're trying to eat? Want to zap screens from across the street? The TV-B-Gone kit is just what you need. With just a simple click of the button you can turn off any TV from 100's of feet away. Zap!
guide.introduction_rendered:
Tired of all those LCD TVs everywhere? Want a break from advertisements while you're trying to eat? Want to zap screens from across the street? The TV-B-Gone kit is just what you need. With just a simple click of the button you can turn off any TV from 100's of feet away. Zap!

Relevant parts
  • Super TV-B-Gone Kit
  • Battery holder
  • Transistor PN 2222
  • Transistor PN 2907
  • IC Microcontroller Chip
  • 8-Pin IC Socket
  • Ceramic capacitor
  • 220uF Electrolytic Capacitor
  • Brown-Black-Red Resistor
  • IR LED
  • IR LED
  • Green LED
  • Tactile switch
  • Blue Ceramic Oscillator
  • Optional 10K Resistor (Outside of USA/Asia)
  • Printed Circuit Board
  • Sticky Foam
Tools
  • Solder
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire cutters

parts.notes: includes all of the following parts:

lines.text: On the first slide for this guide, you will find a list of the supplied parts to build this kit.
lines.text_raw: On the first slide for this guide, you will find a list of the supplied parts to build this kit.

lines.text: Make sure you have all of the required parts.  If you are missing any parts, check under your chair!
lines.text_raw: Make sure you have all of the required parts.  If you are missing any parts, check under your chair!

lines.text: The tactile switch should be soldered into the S1 spot.
lines.text_raw: The tactile switch should be soldered into the '''S1''' spot.

lines.text: It does not matter which way you put it in.
lines.text_raw: It does not matter which way you put it in.

lines.text: Once it is flush with the board, turn it over and solder the connection.
lines.text_raw: Once it is flush with the board, turn it over and solder the connection.

lines.text: Insert one of the Brown-Black-Red Resistors into the R5 position.
lines.text_raw: Insert one of the Brown-Black-Red Resistors into the '''R5''' position.

lines.text: It does not matter which way you put the resistor in.
lines.text_raw: It does not matter which way you put the resistor in.

lines.text: Turn the board over and solder the leads.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over and solder the leads.

lines.text: To make sure the leads stay in when you turn the board over, bend the leads outwards a little bit after inserting them into the PCB.
lines.text_raw: To make sure the leads stay in when you turn the board over, bend the leads outwards a little bit after inserting them into the PCB.

lines.text: To ensure that there are no shorts, be sure to clip the leads of the resistors after they are soldered. Do this for all the components after soldering.
lines.text_raw: To ensure that there are no shorts, be sure to clip the leads of the resistors after they are soldered. Do this for all the components after soldering.

steps.title: Insert the Small Green LED at D5

lines.text: LEDs have one longer lead and one shorter lead.  The longer lead is the positive lead, and the shorter one is the negative lead.
lines.text_raw: LEDs have one longer lead and one shorter lead.  The longer lead is the positive lead, and the shorter one is the negative lead.

lines.text: Insert the longer lead into the hole marked with the (+) sign, and the shorter lead (-) goes into the other hole on the PCB.
lines.text_raw: Insert the longer lead into the hole marked with the (+) sign, and the shorter lead (-) goes into the other hole on the PCB.

lines.text: Turn the board over, and solder the LED in.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over, and solder the LED in.

lines.text: The small yellow .1uF capacitor (marked 104) is to be inserted into C1.
lines.text_raw: The small yellow .1uF capacitor (marked 104) is to be inserted into '''C1'''.

lines.text: This capacitor is not polarized, so it doesn't matter which direction you put it in.  Push it through, bend the leads, and solder.
lines.text_raw: This capacitor is not polarized, so it doesn't matter which direction you put it in.  Push it through, bend the leads, and solder.

lines.text: The ceramic oscillator should be inserted into X1 on the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: The ceramic oscillator should be inserted into '''X1''' on the circuit board.

lines.text: The direction of insertion for this component doesn't matter.
lines.text_raw: The direction of insertion for this component doesn't matter.

lines.text: Turn it over, and solder it in.
lines.text_raw: Turn it over, and solder it in.

lines.text: The 8-Pin Socket must be inserted into the PCB by matching the silkscreened 'notch' printed on the circuit board to the 'notch' on the socket.
lines.text_raw: The 8-Pin Socket must be inserted into the PCB by matching the silkscreened 'notch' printed on the circuit board to the 'notch' on the socket.

lines.text: Make sure the socket is flush with the board, turn it over and solder it in.
lines.text_raw: Make sure the socket is flush with the board, turn it over and solder it in.

lines.text: Begin by trimming the leads on the battery holder until there is only about a quarter of the wire remaining.
lines.text_raw: Begin by trimming the leads on the battery holder until there is only about a quarter of the wire remaining.

lines.text: Strip the ends of the wires so there is about about 1/4 " exposed.
lines.text_raw: Strip the ends of the wires so there is about about 1/4 " exposed.

lines.text: The red wire is inserted into the positive (+) hole, the black wire is inserted into the negative (-) hole in the PCB.
lines.text_raw: The red wire is inserted into the positive (+) hole, the black wire is inserted into the negative (-) hole in the PCB.

lines.text: Turn the board over and solder it in place.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over and solder it in place.

lines.text: To test, put the chip in the 8-Pin socket, add two AA batteries, and your LED light should be blinking.  The chip should be inserted with the dot on the IC facing the notched end of the 8-Pin socket.  Before moving on, remove the batteries from the holder.
lines.text_raw: To test, put the chip in the 8-Pin socket, add two AA batteries, and your LED light should be blinking.  The chip should be inserted with the dot on the IC facing the notched end of the 8-Pin socket.  Before moving on, remove the batteries from the holder.

lines.text: In position R1, insert the other Brown-Black-Red Resistor. Like before, the orientation of the resistor on the PCB does not matter.
lines.text_raw: In position '''R1''', insert the other Brown-Black-Red Resistor.  Like before, the orientation of the resistor on the PCB does not matter.

lines.text: Turn the board over and solder it in.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over and solder it in.

lines.text: The blue capacitor has a longer lead, which is positive (+), and the shorter lead is the negative (-).
lines.text_raw: The blue capacitor has a longer lead, which is positive (+), and the shorter lead is the negative (-).

lines.text: Insert this capacitor into C2, where the longer lead is inserted into the hole marked with a (+).
lines.text_raw: Insert this capacitor into C2, where the longer lead is inserted into the hole marked with a (+).

lines.text: Turn the board over, and solder the leads in.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over, and solder the leads in.

lines.text: The transistor marked 2907 should be inserted into Q5.
lines.text_raw: The transistor marked '''2907''' should be inserted into '''Q5'''.

lines.text: The flat end should be facing outward on the PCB, matching the silkscreen.  Push the transistor through the hole, and solder the leads in.
lines.text_raw: The flat end should be facing outward on the PCB, matching the silkscreen.  Push the transistor through the hole, and solder the leads in.

lines.text: Included in the kit are four NPN (2N2222) transistors. They are soldered into Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4.
lines.text_raw: Included in the kit are four NPN (2N2222) transistors. They are soldered into Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4.

lines.text: Insert each transistor matching the silkscreen on the PCB.
lines.text_raw: Insert each transistor matching the silkscreen on the PCB.

lines.text: Turn the board over, and solder the joints.  Be sure to snip the leads to avoid anything shorting out.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over, and solder the joints.  Be sure to snip the leads to avoid anything shorting out.

lines.text: Each IR LED has a longer lead and a smaller lead.  The longer lead is the positive (+)
lines.text_raw: Each IR LED has a longer lead and a smaller lead.  The longer lead is the positive (+)

lines.text: You will want the LEDs to face forward, so leave some room when you insert the LED into the PCB. (see pictures for LED orientation)
lines.text_raw: You will want the LEDs to face forward, so leave some room when you insert the LED into the PCB. (see pictures for LED orientation)

lines.text: The two 'clear' LEDs go on the outside of the PCB, and the two 'blue' LEDs go on the inside as pictured.
lines.text_raw: The two 'clear' LEDs go on the outside of the PCB, and the two 'blue' LEDs go on the inside as pictured.

lines.text: After you solder the LEDs in, bend them forward.
lines.text_raw: After you solder the LEDs in, bend them forward.

lines.text: Now add two fresh AA batteries you're good to go! Keep in mind that the LED will blink continously if your batteries are low.
lines.text_raw: Now add two fresh AA batteries you're good to go! Keep in mind that the LED will blink continously if your batteries are low.

lines.text: All done!  Take this anywhere you need to zap a TV. Just point and press!
lines.text_raw: All done!  Take this anywhere you need to zap a TV. Just point and press!

lines.text: After hitting the button, the TV-B-Gone will continue to transmit for around 2 minutes, sending all the codes stored in the chip.
lines.text_raw: After hitting the button, the TV-B-Gone will continue to transmit for around 2 minutes, sending all the codes stored in the chip.

lines.text: Enjoy!
lines.text_raw: Enjoy!
